title: Rainford Walks

images.title: Ian Hartley / Rainford Village in early spring
images.caption: Rainford Village in early spring. Taken from the West of the village, the A570 is in the foreground. A field of winter barley is just beginning its growth.

images.title: Raymond Knapman / Cottages next Linear Park in Rainford
images.caption: Cottages next Linear Park in Rainford. These cottages off Cross Pit Lane lie next to the site of a level crossing of the railway line from St Helens to Rainford Junction.

images.title: Rainford Brook by Alexander P Kapp, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Rainford Brook

images.title: Sue Adair / Site of Rainford Colliery (Siding Lane Local Nature Reserve)
images.caption: Site of Rainford Colliery (Siding Lane Local Nature Reserve). Siding Lane Local Nature Reserve occupies the site of the former Rainford Colliery which is located just to the north west of the village. The shaft was sunk through sixteen feet of wet gravel and sand in 1860 and operated until the 1926 coal strike which caused the decline of the pit, finally closing in 1928. There's some nice footpaths here around a small pond.

images.title: Sue Adair / Rainford Hall, Crank
images.caption: Crank Rainford Hall. Crank was the original home of Col. J.P. Pilkington of the famous family of glass manufacturers. It's located to the south east of the village.

images.title: Raymond Knapman / Terrace cottages Kings Moss
images.caption: Terrace cottages Kings Moss

images.title: A quiet moment at Orrell Water Park by Raymond Knapman, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: A quiet moment at Orrell Water Park

description: This village is in a good spot for exploring the Mersey Forest. The village has some nice country trails, a local nature reserve and is also very close to the highest point in the county. This walk from the village heads east to climb to the viewpoint at Billinge Hill before visiting Orrell Water Park. The walk starts in the village and heads east through the Mersey Forest to Kings Moss. You continue north east past Brownlow before turning south to climb to Billinge Hill, the highest point in Merseyside. From the 179 m (587 ft) summit  there are excellent views towards Great Orme in Wales, Blackpool tower, Greater Manchester, Winter Hill and the Derbyshire Peak District. You'll also see a beacon tower at the summit and several large transmitter masts nearby. After taking in the views head north past Longshaw to visit Orrel Water Park. Here you'll find footpaths taking you to two pretty reservoirs surrounded by attractive woodland and a buttercup meadow.
